\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Base class for datagram sockets. 

Datagram sockets are normally connectionless, where each packet is individually routed and delivered.

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{clone()}{clone()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1datagram__socket_a657f28c77ef637bbabcc7eef663f6255} 
\mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1datagram__socket}{datagram\+\_\+socket}} sockpp\+::datagram\+\_\+socket\+::clone (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}{}{}\end{DoxyParamCaption}) const\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [inline]}}



Creates a new datagram socket that refers to this one. 

This creates a new object with an independent lifetime, but refers back to this same socket. On most systems, this duplicates the file handle using the dup() call. A typical use of this is to have separate threads for reading and writing the socket. One thread would get the original socket and the other would get the cloned one. \begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A new datagram socket object that refers to the same socket as this one. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{connect()}{connect()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1datagram__socket_ae4e7edff7afb67613e182402a7868085} 
\mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}} sockpp\+::datagram\+\_\+socket\+::connect (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{const \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1sock__address}{sock\+\_\+address}} \&}]{addr}{}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [inline]}}



Connects the socket to the remote address. 

In the case of datagram sockets, this does not create an actual connection, but rather specifies the address to which datagrams are sent by default and the only address from which packets are received. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
